procedure: Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty, right shoulder
extraction_data.summary: 72-year-old female with cuff tear arthropathy of the right shoulder underwent reverse total shoulder arthroplasty. The procedure was performed using a deltopectoral approach with subscapularis release, humeral head resection, glenoid baseplate placement with screws, and humeral component insertion. No complications were reported, and the patient was placed in an abduction pillow with non-weight-bearing instructions for the upper extremity.

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

documentation: Medical records documentation may be required to assess whether the member meets the clinical criteria for coverage (Evidence: pg no: 1, L40-L42)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

documentation: Medical records documentation may be required to assess whether the member meets the clinical criteria for coverage (Evidence: pg no: 1, L40-L42)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty is similar to standard arthroplasty in that both components of the joint are replaced but the ball and socket portions of the joint are reversed, allowing the deltoid muscle to assume partial function of the rotator cuff. exclusions: Total shoulder arthroplasty or hemiarthroplasty under conditions which would result in excessive stress on the implant including, but not limited to, Charcot joint and paralytic conditions of the shoulder (Evidence: pg no: 11, L332-L333)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, glenohumeral joint; hemiarthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 11, L363)

(Evidence: pg no: 10, L296-L299)

original_chart:
OPERATIVE REPORT

Patient Name: Eleanor Brooks
MRN: 315879642
Date of Service: November 4, 2025
Surgeon: Dr. Jonathan Reed, MD

PROCEDURE PERFORMED:
1. Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty, right shoulder

INDICATIONS:
72-year-old female with cuff tear arthropathy and severe shoulder dysfunction.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
1. Cuff tear arthropathy, right shoulder

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Same as above.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
Patient placed in beach chair position. Deltopectoral approach utilized. Subscapularis released for exposure. Humeral head resected and canal prepared. Glenoid exposure achieved and baseplate secured with screws. Glenosphere impacted. Humeral component inserted with trial reduction demonstrating stability. Final implants inserted and wound closed in layers.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Not recorded.
COMPLICATIONS: None.
DRAINS: None.

IMPLANTS:
Reverse shoulder system implanted. Specific component sizes not specified.

POSTOPERATIVE PLAN:
Abduction pillow applied. Non-weight-bearing upper extremity. Follow-up in two weeks. Detailed rehab protocol to be outlined at first postoperative visit.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
After obtaining informed consent and confirming the surgical site, the patient was brought to the operating room and placed in beach chair position. The right shoulder was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.

A standard deltopectoral approach was utilized. The cephalic vein was identified and retracted laterally. The interval between the deltoid and pectoralis major was developed. The subscapularis was identified and released for exposure of the glenohumeral joint.

Upon entering the joint, significant [NEEDS PHYSICIAN INPUT: specific intraoperative findings regarding rotator cuff and articular surfaces] were noted, confirming the preoperative diagnosis of cuff tear arthropathy.

The humeral head was resected at the anatomic neck using an oscillating saw. The humeral canal was then prepared with sequential reamers to [NEEDS PHYSICIAN INPUT: specific reamer size] mm. The glenoid was exposed, and [NEEDS PHYSICIAN INPUT: specific details of glenoid preparation] was performed.

The glenoid baseplate was secured with [NEEDS PHYSICIAN INPUT: number and size of screws] screws, achieving excellent fixation. The [NEEDS PHYSICIAN INPUT: size] mm glenosphere was then impacted onto the baseplate.

The humeral component was inserted with [NEEDS PHYSICIAN INPUT: details of cement usage if applicable]. Trial reduction demonstrated [NEEDS PHYSICIAN INPUT: specific details of stability testing] stability throughout the range of motion. The final implants were inserted, and the subscapularis was repaired using [NEEDS PHYSICIAN INPUT: specific repair technique and suture type].

The wound was copiously irrigated and closed in layers. Skin was closed with [NEEDS PHYSICIAN INPUT: specific closure material]. Sterile dressings were applied.

user_input_required.reason: Duration of symptoms is required to establish chronicity and medical necessity for surgical intervention.
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific duration of symptoms in months (e.g., '8 months of progressive shoulder pain and dysfunction').

user_input_required.reason: Pain severity documentation helps establish functional impact and medical necessity.
user_input_required.suggestion: Document pain severity using a standard scale (e.g., '8/10 pain with overhead activities').

user_input_required.reason: Specific functional limitations demonstrate impact on activities of daily living and support medical necessity.
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific activities affected (e.g., 'unable to reach overhead, difficulty with dressing, unable to sleep on affected side').

user_input_required.reason: Failed conservative management is a key criterion for surgical intervention approval.
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific treatments attempted (e.g., 'physical therapy, NSAIDs, activity modification, corticosteroid injections') and duration (e.g., '4 months').

user_input_required.reason: Objective measurements document functional impairment and support medical necessity.
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific measurements for forward flexion, abduction, internal and external rotation compared to contralateral side.

user_input_required.reason: Strength deficits document functional impairment and support medical necessity.
user_input_required.suggestion: Document strength using standard grading scale (e.g., '3/5 strength in abduction and external rotation').

user_input_required.reason: Positive impingement tests support diagnosis and medical necessity.
user_input_required.suggestion: Document results of Neer and Hawkins-Kennedy impingement tests.

user_input_required.reason: Imaging findings confirm diagnosis and support medical necessity for surgical intervention.
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific MRI/CT findings including details of rotator cuff tear, glenohumeral arthritis, and any other relevant pathology.

user_input_required.reason: Intraoperative findings confirm preoperative diagnosis and support medical necessity.
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific findings regarding rotator cuff and articular surfaces observed during surgery.

user_input_required.reason: Complete documentation of implanted devices is required for proper coding and billing.
user_input_required.suggestion: Document manufacturer, model, and size for all implanted components.

The procedure description was minimal and implant details were not specified.
